Quantum mechanics is a fundamental theory in physics that describes the behavior of matter and energy at the smallest scales, much smaller than what can be seen with the naked eye. It is a mathematical framework that explains the behavior of particles and their interactions with each other.

The principles of quantum mechanics are different from those of classical physics, which is what we experience in our everyday lives. In quantum mechanics, particles can exist in multiple states at the same time, and their behavior is described by probability rather than determinism. The act of measuring a particle can also change its state, which is known as the observer effect.

Quantum mechanics has many practical applications in modern technology, including transistors, lasers, and cryptography. It also helps us understand some of the most fundamental aspects of the universe, such as the behavior of atoms and subatomic particles.
